newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Gowda reaffirms stand on nuclear treaty.
newsitem.headline: India's Gowda reaffirms stand on nuclear treaty.

text.p: Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda on Wednesday reaffirmed the country's commitment to nuclear disarmament, vowing not to be a party to any "discriminatory" goals along the way.

"We believe nuclear disarmament is vital for the future of humanity and would like to work towards this goal. However, till the goal is accepted by all, we cannot afford to subscribe to any goal that is discriminatory, unfair and inimical to national security interests," Deve Gowda told a gathering of scientists.
India has vetoed the comprehensive test ban treaty (CTBT) being negotiated in Geneva and pledged to oppose any effort to send the treaty to the United Nations General Assembly.

New Delhi says the treaty is discriminatory because it fails to spell out a timetable for nuclear disarmament for the five declared nuclear powers and allows them to refine arsenals through computerised testing while barring other nations from tests.
Deve Gowda was speaking to a gathering of scientists at the Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (BARC) on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of India's first nuclear reactor, Apsara.
"We believe the power of atom should be used for peace and not for nuclear weapons," Gowda told the meeting.
